Description: A full stack project creating an easier way to schedule meetings.
Tools: Golang, JS, AWS, Docker, SQL, HTML
LongerDesc: This was my final project for INFO 441, Server-Side Development, and it was the first project where I was able to completely finish from prototype to product! As exciting as this milestone was, the steps to reach this were arduous and painstaking, but I developed an understanding of many concepts like Microservices, RestAPIs, Session Storage, and Middleware. Working in a group of 4, we created a way to schedule meetings, where the members of a specific group could see all of the available times of all members. The site implemented HTTPS and Login/Logout for users to protect user information. We also used relational theory to efficiently access the user information and free times.

Description: A web application to optimize your walking routes.
LongerDesc: In Client-Side Development, I worked with my partner to create an application for users to find cool places to spice up their walking paths. Using MapBox, the Overpass API, and the Google Places API, we used the user’s location information and preferences to scope out places of interest for them. Another feature includes adding the places in their results to a “Favorites” page for future reference.

Description: Creating a physical and logical Relational Database for handling calls for emergency services
LongerDesc: I did not think I would have an affinity for relational databases at the beginning of the quarter, but after completing this Emergency Services Database, I gained respect and admiration for it (I promise I’m not being sardonic). My team of 3 people researched the Greater Seattle Area’s emergency response and designed our database to follow the guidelines.

Description: Designing a more convenient way to find parking in Seattle
LongerDesc: In my Design Thinking course, I became aware of all of the details and research necessary to even create a low fidelity prototype for a specific issue.  Creating a high fidelity prototype, design specification, and prototype video gave me a better understanding and appreciation of the user experience process. For our final project, my team and I wanted to alleviate some stress of finding parking for drivers in Seattle.

The HuskyTech Datathon was actually my first hackathon/datathon experience! It was so fun to utilize my data science skills from class for something that was not a homework assignment. Our team won Best Insight for our presentation!
